xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: This research was funded by the Chula-Stanford and SURGE projects under Chevron UPP through Stanford University , and the Ratchadapisek Sompoch Endowment Fund (2014) through Chulalongkorn University ( CU-56-014-FC , Sci-Super 2014-14). Field assistance and the facilities for the research in Thailand were generously provided by the Department of Geology, Chulalongkorn University. Antonino Cilona is thanked for the support provided in the field and for his comments on an early version of this manuscript. Fiona Walter is thanked for English language correction of this manuscript. We thank the two reviewers and the Editor Ian Alsop for their comments that improved the manuscript.

organization.$: Department of Geological and Environmental Sciences

head.citation-title: Structural characterization of the fracture systems in the porcelanites: Comparing data from the Monterey Formation in California USA and the Sap Bon Formation in Central Thailand
head.abstracts: © 2016 Elsevier LtdThe fractures in the porcelanites from the Monterey Formation in California USA and the Sap Bon Formation in Central Thailand were documented for a comparative study of their modes, distribution, and their relationship to other structures such as folds and bedding planes. Both formations consist in thinly bedded stiff units that are prone to folding, flexural slip, and cross-bedding brittle fracturing under compression. There are two assemblages in the porcelanites. The first assemblage includes commonly vertical high-angle opening mode fractures, left-lateral strike-slip faults, normal faults, and thrust faults. The second one is sub-horizontal fractures which are associated with folds, bedding slip, and thrusts faults in both Monterey and Sap Bon formations. The structural architectures of these rocks and the associated groups of structures are remarkably similar in terms of both opening and shearing modes and their relationships with the bedding due to their depositional architecture and the compressional tectonic regimes, in spite of the fact that the two locations are more than ten thousand kilometers apart and have very different ages of deformation.

grant-text.$: This research was funded by the Chula-Stanford and SURGE projects under Chevron UPP through Stanford University, and the Ratchadapisek Sompoch Endowment Fund (2014) through Chulalongkorn University (CU-56-014-FC, Sci-Super 2014-14). Field assistance and the facilities for the research in Thailand were generously provided by the Department of Geology, Chulalongkorn University. Antonino Cilona is thanked for the support provided in the field and for his comments on an early version of this manuscript. Fiona Walter is thanked for English language correction of this manuscript. We thank the two reviewers and the Editor Ian Alsop for their comments that improved the manuscript.
